question: Which of the following transport proteins is mainly responsible for transporting fructose across the brush border epithelium of the small intestine?
Which of the following enzymes present on the brush border epithelium of the intestine breaks down 1,6-glycosidic linkages?
A 48-year-old male with a severe deficiency of pancreatic lipase consumes a high-fat meal. Which of the physiological events is most likely to occur in this challenging situation?

A patient comes to the clinic with a complaint of pain in the epigastric region for past 2-3 months. Pain is apparent 2-3 hours after taking a meal. A peptic ulcer is suspected. Which is the most common area for a ulcer to be found in?

The secretion of pancreatic enzymes is regulated by various hormones and neural mechanisms, particularly in response to food intake. Which hormone plays a key role in decreasing gastric emptying and stimulating the secretion of pancreatic enzymes in response to the presence of fatty acids and amino acids in the duodenum?
Which of the following is a ventral mesogastrium derivative?

A 54-year-old alcoholic male presents with a sudden onset of severe, constant, epigastric pain that radiates to his midback. Further evaluation finds fever, steatorrhea, and discoloration around his flank and umbilicus, Lab investigation reveals elevated serum amylase and lipase levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 23-year-old primigravida gives birth at term. Ultrasound examination before delivery showed polyhydramnios. It is noted that the infant vomits all feedings, then develops a fever and difficulty with respiration within 2 days. The radiograph shows both lungs and the heart are of normal size, but there are no pulmonary infiltrates or stomach bubbles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which one of the following statements best describes the microscopic findings in autoimmune pancreatitis?

answers.option: Duct-centric mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate, venulitis, and increased plasma cells
Dilated ducts with eosinophilic ductal concretions with increased neutrophils
Necrosis of acinar and ductal tissues and necrosis of islets of Langerhans
Extensive fibrosis and atrophy have left only residual islets and ducts with a sprinkling of chronic exudate
Extensive hemorrhage within the substance of the gland with increased neutrophils

question: Which of the following is the least likely to be visualized in a microscope when examining a gastric biopsy from a patient with acute gastritis?
Which of the following presents with symptoms of obstruction as well as compromised blood supply?

A middle-aged woman without significant past medical history presents with acute onset of fatigue and jaundice. Blood tests show markedly elevated aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase, and high titer antinuclear antibody. Serologies for smooth muscle antibody and anti-mitochondrial antibody are both positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a contributor to circulatory disorders of the liver?

The portal vein is the blood vessel that brings blood to the liver from the intestines. Portal vein thrombosis is the blockage or narrowing of the portal vein by a blood clot. Which of the following symptoms do most people with portal vein thrombosis have?

The development of the midgut is characterized by rapid elongation, herniation, and rotation of the midgut loop. Rotation of the midgut loop occurs during herniation (about 90°) as well as during the return of the intestinal loops into the abdominal cavity (remaining 180°). Axis for rotation is formed by:
What is the correct position of the uncinate process of the pancreas?

answers.option: In front of the inferior mesenteric vessels
In front of the superior mesenteric vessels

question: A student is observing a tissue slide under the microscope showing permanent circular folds of mucosa with a core of submucosa. Which of the following is the most likely structure?
Salivary cells secrete which of the following enzymes that activates a vasodilator present in the blood, allowing for increased nutrition to salivary glands?
The oxidation of lactic acid to pyruvic acid requires which of the following vitamin derivatives to act as the hydrogen carrier?
Which is an important enzyme of the HMP shunt pathway that is involved in regulation?

A histological section is being observed showing a serous gland of compound tubulo-acinar variety. The secretory unit consists of pyramidal serous cells and specialized pale, low cuboidal epithelial cells. Numerous spherical cell clusters are also scattered. Which of the following structures is being observed?
During abdominal surgery, a surgeon needs to locate the lesion in the jejunum. Which of the following statements will the surgeon consider when identifying the jejunum?

answers.option: Mostly lying in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen
Has fewer arterial arcade than ileum
Has fewer circular folds in lumen than ileum

question: A surgeon has to perform an exploratory laparotomy on a 45-year-old male to see an intra-abdominal lesion. During the surgical procedure, the surgeon needs to be aware of the anatomy of the rectus sheath. In this regard, which of the following structures is involved in forming the posterior layer of the rectus sheath above the arcuate line?
While examining a cadaver, a branch of the gastroduodenal artery, the right gastro-omental artery, is observed running in the following ligament of the peritoneum:

During abdominal surgery, the surgeon made an incision on the anterolateral abdominal wall. After the skin and fascia, the surgeon started incising the muscle layers. The surgeon observed a layer of muscle fibers going upward towards the midline, in an oblique direction. Which of the following muscles was the surgeon observing?
The part of the stomach, having an orifice lying 2–4 cm to the left from the median plane at the level of the T11 vertebra, is called:

A 20-year-old man came into the emergency with severe pain in the lower abdomen and vomiting. After examination and investigation, it was diagnosed that the appendix was inflamed. Part of the intestine in which the inflamed tube opens is:
Lymphoid tissue present in the wall of the gastrointestinal tract is called MALT. Which layer of the gastrointestinal tract contains MALT?
When examining the histology of the gallbladder under light microscopy, which of the following features is not correct?

answers.option: Lining epithelium is simple columnar type
Muscularis layer contains interlacing bundles of smooth muscle
In neck region, submucosa contains simple branch tubuloalveolar glands
Short microvilli are present at the apical surface of tall cells

question: Liver, biliary apparatus (hepatic ducts, gallbladder, and bile duct), and pancreas are derived from the foregut. Which of the following germ layers gives rise to the parenchyma of these glands?
Concerning the histological features of the duodenum, leaf-like projections covered by a simple columnar epithelium having a core of loose connective tissue in the duodenum are:

In the histology practical of the gastrointestinal module, a second-year medical student looking at a slide of an organ under the microscope, observes a thin muscular layer forming a boundary between the innermost mucosal layer and the connective tissue below. Which of the following structures did he observe?
The midgut begins from the lower half of the duodenum to the right two-thirds of the transverse colon. The part which develops from the cephalic limb of the primary intestinal loop is the:
Which of the following vascular lymphoid organs is derived from the mesenchyme of the dorsal mesogastrium of the gastrointestinal tract?
A 45-year-old patient reports difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids. Which phase of swallowing is most likely affected?
A patient with a brainstem stroke presents with dysphagia. Which neural structure is primarily responsible for coordinating the pharyngeal phase of swallowing?
After a meal, a patient experiences rapid gastric emptying, leading to diarrhea and hypoglycemia. Dysfunction of which gastric process is the most likely cause?
After a meal, a patient experiences a spike in gastric acid secretion. This increase is most directly due to the activation of which of the following receptors on parietal cells?
A patient presents with jaundice and pale stools. Lab results show elevated direct bilirubin. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
A patient with severe liver disease is found to have hypoglycemia during fasting. Which of the following liver functions is most likely impaired?

A patient presents with frequent episodes of postprandial hypoglycemia. A glucose tolerance test shows delayed absorption of glucose from the lumen. Which of the following transporters is most likely defective?
A 60-year-old man with pancreatic insufficiency has difficulty digesting carbohydrates. Which stage of carbohydrate digestion is most affected in this condition?
Bile salts are amphipathic chemicals that emulsify fat globules into smaller ones. Micelles form as fat droplets shrink. What makes bile micelles?
Which of the following is the primary cause of pancreatic insufficiency in cystic fibrosis?

answers.option: Blockage of pancreatic ducts by thick mucus

question: A 50-year-old patient with a history of protein malabsorption presents with unexplained weight loss and fatigue. Investigations indicate incomplete peptide digestion in the small intestine. Which enzyme, responsible for breaking peptides down into individual amino acids, is most likely deficient in this patient?
A patient eats a meal rich in fats, and shortly after, the hormone cholecystokinin (CCK) is released. The primary function of cholecystokinin in relation to fats digestion is:

answers.option: It increases the production of bile by the liver
It promotes the absorption of bile salts in the ileum
It causes the gallbladder to contract and release stored bile into the intestine
It stimulates the pancreas to release insulin for fat digestion
It reduces gastric acid secretion to protect the intestines

question: Ali has been fasting for 48 hours, and his glycogen stores are depleted. What is his body primarily using for energy at this point?

A mother brings her 2-month-old child to the hospital, concerned about the child's diapers, which are stained with dark urine. She notices that the stains become more blackish upon exposure to air. The physician conducts Benedict’s test, which comes back positive, while a test for glucose shows negative results. Based on the symptoms and test results, which of the following metabolic disorders is most likely responsible for the child’s condition?
High energy level of the biological system is determined by an increased ratio of:

A man presents to the emergency room after ingesting an insecticide. His respiratory rate is very low. Information from the poison control center indicates that this particular insecticide binds to and completely inhibits cytochrome c. The problem in this man’s mitochondria is:

answers.option: Complex III would be in a reduced state
The rate of ATP synthesis would be increased
Cytochromes a and a3 would be in the reduced state
Coenzyme Q would be in the oxidized state
Complex I would be in a oxidized state

question: Thiamine (vitamin B1) acts as a coenzyme in several oxidative decarboxylation reactions during the metabolism. What is the active form of thiamine?
In McArdle's disease (GSD Type V), the deficiency of which enzyme leads to muscle cramps during exercise?
The TCA cycle begins with the formation of a 6-carbon compound as a result of the reaction between:
Which of the following is allosterically stimulated by NADP+ and is the rate-controlling enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway (HMP shunt)?

Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid. Besides its incorporation into proteins, the important function of phenylalanine is its conversion to tyrosine. Which enzyme catalyzes the hydroxylation of phenylalanine into tyrosine?

A 42-year-old female presents to her primary care provider for fatigue. She states that she has been on a religious fast. Upon inquiry, she explains that she has only been drinking water for the past eight days. Which of the following enzymes is most active in this patient at this time?
The action of intestinal urease to form NH3 is clinically significant in which of the following?

A 58-year-old lady, with recurrent episodes of subacute intestinal obstruction for 20 years, presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of constipation and abdominal distension for 3 days. Her initial X-rays were normal but then she developed abdominal pain and ultrasound showed free fluid in Morrison’s pouch. As a suspected case of bowel perforation, you advise her a small bowel dynamic fluoroscopic study. What will be the contrast agent of choice in this patient?
Regarding segmental anatomy of liver on contrast enhanced CT abdomen, which of the following structures divide the liver into eight segments?
Which physiological mechanism is primarily responsible for preventing acid reflux into the esophagus under normal conditions?

answers.option: Contraction of the upper esophageal sphincter
Secretion of protective mucus by the esophagus
Increased production of bicarbonate by the stomach
Tonic contraction of the lower esophageal sphincter

question: A 45-year-old male presents with a year-long history of heartburn and regurgitation, worsened by lying down, and recent difficulty swallowing solid foods. He reports temporary relief with antacids. An upper GI endoscopy reveals red, irregular, salmon-colored mucosa extending from the gastroesophageal junction into the lower esophagus. Biopsy confirms the presence of intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells replacing the normal squamous epithelium. The patient has a history of occasional alcohol use and smoking but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following best explains the cellular changes observed in the biopsy of the patient’s esophagus?

answers.option: Chronic acid exposure resulting in intestinal metaplasia
Conversion of columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium
Increased proliferation of esophageal squamous cells
Chronic irritation leading to squamous metaplasia

question: Which nerve is primarily responsible for the relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter?

A 45-year-old male presents with a year-long history of heartburn and regurgitation, worsened by lying down, and recent difficulty swallowing solid foods. He reports temporary relief with antacids but recurrent symptoms. An upper GI endoscopy reveals red, irregular, salmon-colored mucosa extending from the gastroesophageal junction into the lower esophagus. Biopsy confirms the presence of intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells replacing the normal squamous epithelium. The patient has a history of occasional alcohol use and smoking but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following best explains how gastric acid contributes to this patient’s symptoms and condition?

answers.option: Gastric acid reflux into the esophagus damages the mucosa
Gastric acid helps activate pepsinogen in the esophagus
Gastric acid secretion is decreased in GERD
Gastric acid aids in neutralizing bile salts

question: A 45-year-old male presents with a year-long history of heartburn and regurgitation, worsened by lying down, and recent difficulty swallowing solid foods. He reports temporary relief with antacids but recurrent symptoms. An upper GI endoscopy reveals red, irregular, salmon-colored mucosa extending from the gastroesophageal junction into the lower esophagus. Biopsy confirms the presence of intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells replacing the normal squamous epithelium. The patient has a history of occasional alcohol use and smoking but is otherwise healthy. Which of the following structures provides the arterial supply to the lower esophagus, where the abnormal changes were observed?

A 45-year-old male presents with a year-long history of heartburn and regurgitation, worsened by lying down, and recent difficulty swallowing solid foods. He reports temporary relief with antacids but recurrent symptoms. An upper GI endoscopy reveals red, irregular, salmon-colored mucosa extending from the gastroesophageal junction into the lower esophagus. Biopsy confirms the presence of intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells replacing the normal squamous epithelium. The patient has a history of occasional alcohol use and smoking but is otherwise healthy. What is the primary mechanism by which antacids provide temporary relief in this patient’s condition?

answers.option: Antacids stimulate mucous production in the esophagus, protecting the mucosal lining
Antacids neutralize gastric acid, temporarily raising the pH and reducing mucosal irritation
Antacids decrease gastric acid secretion by inhibiting proton pumps in parietal cells
Antacids reduce gastric acid by blocking histamine receptors on parietal cells
Antacids enhance gastric emptying, reducing the likelihood of reflux

question: Besides clinical history, what is the basic morphological feature that supports the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis instead of acute pancreatitis?

answers.option: Necrosis of acinar and ductal tissue

question: No single test for H. Pylori is considered the gold standard. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis accurately?

answers.option: Serologic test for antibodies to bacteria
Rapid urease test using gastric biopsy
Bacterial DNA detection by PCR using gastric biopsy
Urea breath test (based on generation of NH3 by bacterial urease)

question: A 1-week-old male neonate is brought to the emergency department by his parents. The baby appears sluggish and breathing rapidly. The mother explains that her baby has been fussy for the last several days and is not feeding well. Today, he has been vomiting a lot and is very sleepy. The pregnancy was uneventful, and the baby was delivered by normal vaginal birth. Blood studies reveal a normal anion gap. Which of the following pathological processes is most likely responsible for these symptoms?

answers.option: Hyperammonemia due to an error of the urea cycle
Long-chain fatty acids accumulation due to carnitine deficiency
Phenylketonuria due to phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency

question: A 16-year-old young male came to the outpatient department with complaints of right upper abdominal pain, nausea, and dark urine for the past week. He was a smoker but recently developed a distaste for cigarettes. He recently returned from his native town in interior Sindh. His cousin who accompanied him also had similar complaints. What is the most likely cause of hepatitis in this case?
What is the most common cause of Traveler’s diarrhea?
What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis in adults?

A 45-year-old male with a 15-year history of heavy alcohol consumption (an average of 8-10 drinks daily) presents to the clinic with weakness, weight loss, and abdominal pain. A liver ultrasound shows fatty liver changes and the patient is diagnosed with alcoholic liver disease. The physician explains that the development of alcoholic liver disease involves several mechanisms, including metabolic, inflammatory, and oxidative processes. Which of the following mechanisms is most directly involved in the early stages of alcoholic liver disease pathogenesis?

answers.option: Direct hepatocyte damage by acetaldehyde, a toxic alcohol metabolite
Deposition of amyloid proteins in hepatocytes
Activation of stellate cells causing fibrosis
Increased oxidative stress leading to lipid peroxidation

question: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with worsening right upper quadrant pain, high fever, and shortness of breath. He was diagnosed with an amoebic liver abscess two weeks ago and started on metronidazole. Despite treatment, his symptoms have worsened. On physical examination, he has decreased breath sounds on the right side and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. A chest X-ray shows an elevated right hemidiaphragm with pleural effusion. Laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and mildly raised liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings in this patient?

answers.option: Chronic granulomatous inflammation of the liver
Rupture into the pleural cavity causing a pleural effusion
Portal vein thrombosis leading to bowel ischemia
Septicemia secondary to acute kidney injury

question: Which of the following is the most likely complication of untreated nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)?
Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of sinusoidal obstruction syndrome?

answers.option: Hepatocyte necrosis due to ischemic injury
Bacterial infection leading to liver abscess formation
Damage to endothelial cells lining the hepatic sinusoids by chemotherapy
Viral hepatitis causing damage to hepatic sinusoids

question: Which of the following is the most likely cause of portal hypertension?

answers.option: Hepatic cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use

question: Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of duodenal perforation?
What is the most common cause of cholestatic syndrome in adults?

A 65-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis secondary to chronic hepatitis C presents to the emergency department with hematemesis, confusion, lethargy, and inappropriate behavior. His family reports that he has been increasingly disoriented over the past two days. On examination, he has jaundice, ascites, and asterixis (flapping tremor). Laboratory tests reveal elevated ammonia levels. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor for this patient’s condition?
In order to neutralize the acidic chyme, which hormone stimulates the pancreas to produce an alkaline bicarbonate solution and deliver it to the duodenum?
